questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
User1 and User2 plan to use Sync your settings.
On which devices can the users use Sync your settings? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: Correct

User1 - Group A, ESR enabled. Group 1 devices - 1 and 2 (device 3 is personally owned)
User 2 - Group B, ESR not enabled.
Another out of date one?

comments.content:
Other opinions can be found here:
https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/microsoft/view/63126-exam-md-101-topic-12-question-1-discussion/
Unless bc its personally owned but that still wouldn't make sense since the given answer is 1234&5
Going with the given answer assuming that ESR settings can sync across corporately owned devices and personal devices

I thought Group 1 Also applied to Device 3

User 1- 1,2,3
User 2 No Devies

Someone explain why 3 wouldn't be included in neither to Mods Answer or in the comments.

discussion.content:
Wrong.
User1 - Group A, ESR enabled. Group 1 devices - 1 and 2
User 2 - Group B, ESR not enabled.

comments.content: Also, the "Sync your settings" option is greyed out for all domain users, even if the domain user has connected a Microsoft account for other apps (e-mail, calendar, store, etc.).

discussion.content:
I could only agree with this answer thinking that User1 is in GroupA, then using Enterprise State Roaming and not the Sync your settings feature.
User2 is an Azure AD joined device local administrator not included in the ESR. So he "could" use Sync your settings. But the documentation says: When Sync settings is turned on, Windows syncs the settings you choose across all your Windows 10 devices that you've signed in to with your Microsoft account. To stop syncing your settings and remove them from the cloud, turn off synced settings on all the devices connected to your Microsoft account. I don't see Microsoft Accounts in this case. Very odd question.
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/about-windows-backup-and-sync-settings-deebcba2-5bc0-4e63-279a-329926955708#WindowsVersion=Windows_10
Correct

My answer is C

I dont think User 2 can, they are not in the MDM scope and they are just local admins...

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/roles/permissions-reference#azure-ad-joined-device-local-administrator

Selected Answer: D
all of them because:
user1 and User3 are in GroupA
user2 is azure ad joined device local admin this group is created when user with the ability to enroll win10 devices enrolls the device and be automatically part of that group
user4: global admin
The point is User2 and User3 are very limited users no Azure AD.

comments.content: User3 is in GroupA as well?
User1 is in GroupA (MDM user scope: GroupA), and User4 is a Global Administrator.

questions.answer_description: All the users can enroll devices to Intune.
questions.question_text: Which user can enroll Device6 in Intune?

HOTSPOT -
You implement the planned changes for Connection1 and Connection2.
How many VPN connections will there be for User1 when the user signs in to Device1 and Device2? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Answers provided are wrong.
User1 is in GroupA. So:
2- Device1: VPN1 (pre configured) and VPN2 (added by Group A)
3- Device2: VPN1 and VPN3 (pre configured), VPN2 (added by Group A)

comments.content:
For Device2, why 3? I dont see a 3rd VPN profile. 

Also, User and Device groups cant be mixed and one will be ignored right? Since Group1 is a device group and GroupA is a user group.

So wouldnt it be 2 VPN Profiles on Device2?

discussion.content: 2 and 2

So from the comments, it seems that VPN configuration profiles only apply to users, correct? Documentation seems to focus on users as well. With that, RodrigoT would be correct. 

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/remote/remote-access/how-to-aovpn-conditional-access

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: 2 -
Device1 has VPN1 and VPN2.

Box 2: 3 -
Device2 has VPN1, VPN2 (group assignment), and VPN3

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
The first answer is wrong.
N-Device1 Group1: Policy1 and Policy2 - No secure Boot
N-Device4 Group2: Policy3 - No BitLocker
Y-Device5 Group3: No policy applied
Mark devices with no compliance policy assigned as Compliant is set
That first one is sneaky.
No No Yes

the first answer is wrong 
its NNY

comments.content: Why would device be No? It is a member of Group 1 which has Bit-locker requirement and also is enable on device 1... Secure Boot is not required in the policy.
But there is also policy 2 assigned to group 1 so policy 1 is a compliment but policy 2 not compliment

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
My opinion:
N- User1 - GroupA and not using AppA.exe
Y- User2 - GroupB and Azure AD joined device local administrator. Users with this role become local machine administrators on all Windows 10 devices that are joined to Azure Active Directory. Link:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/roles/permissions-reference#azure-ad-joined-device-local-administrator
Y- User3 - The Desktop folder is not protected.

Reference supporting RodrigoT and raduM that Desktop is not protected by Controlled folder access: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/defender-endpoint/controlled-folders?view=o365-worldwide#windows-system-folders-are-protected-by-default, Desktop is missing from that list.

NoÂ´No Yes. User will be a local administrator, however the protected folders are set via intune so he cannot modify the setting localy.
User 3 can do anything he wants on his own desktop.
Can anyone explain why user3 can't create a file on his own desktop?

comments.content: yes so? he can do anything on his own desktop.

discussion.content: The Global reader role is a read-only version of the Global administrator role, which allows you to view all settings and administrative information across Microsoft 365. You can use the Global reader role for planning, audits, and investigations.
